author: liberosist
content:
Rollups - particularly zkRs - have much weaker security (edit, to clarify: honesty/trust) assumptions than L1s, and *can* thus scale farther. Optimism, Matter Labs and Offchain Labs have clearly announced that they intend to scale past L1 over time. Whether this is a good idea or not - and I'm well aware of your opinion on the matter - is a different matter, but we *will* see rollups scale past L1's ~1.1M gas/second limit. 

I'm intrigued to see Fuel's approach with UTXOs, though!

author: sky.cactus
content: Do you mean optimistic rollups?

author: sky.cactus
content: zkRollups are generally considered to be significantly better (security wise) than optimistic rollups.

author: liberosist
content: Sure, which is what I meant by "(particularly zkRs)"

author: sky.cactus
content: > Rollups - particularly zkRs - have much **weaker** security assumptions

author: sky.cactus
content:
A more accurate statement would be:
> Rollups - particularly **optimistic rollups** - have much weaker security assumptions

author: sky.cactus
content: L1 > zkR > OR

author: sky.cactus
content: zkR security assumptions are fairly close to L1 security assumptions I believe.

author: liberosist
content:
There's no doubt that L1 has the highest security, followed by zkR, followed by OR 

What I meant was probably "safety assumption", or "trust assumption" - feel free to correct the semantics here. Which is to say, L1s require a N/2 of N, ORs 1 of N as you still need one honest validator, zkRs can eventually get to negligible of N

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think zkRollups need an honest validator?

author: sky.cactus
content: IIUC, the proof is validated on Ethereum, and it is either valid or invalid.  There is no possibility for someone submitting a fraudulent proof to L1 in a zkR.

author: sky.cactus
content: With an OR, you *do* need at least one person validating the submitting assertions to L1 and then that person must submit a fraud proof within the withdraw window.

author: liberosist
content: Exactly what I meant! ORs require one honest validator, zkRs require none, so the burden of having multiple users verifying full nodes on commodity hardware is mitigated, hence the argument that we can't scale farther than L1 doesn't really apply.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oooh, I see.  You are trying to say that Rollups require lower assumptions about the honesty of ecosystem participants than L1 .

author: liberosist
content: Exactly, apologies if the semantics are confusing

author: sky.cactus
content: This has the one major caveat that they still require all of the honesty of the L1 participants as required by the L1 they are bound to.

author: liberosist
content: That is quite true, but L1 does not need to run rollups' full nodes - L1 continues to work with within L1's gas limits.

author: liberosist
content: On a practical note, I see there's at least 3 liquidity bridges available on Arbitrum One at launch - Hop, Connext, and Celer cBridge (possibly also Biconomy if their solution is ready), presumably with many liquidity providers. At the very least, they are required to watch and verify there's no fraud before accepting withdrawals. I'm not trying to say that optimistic rollups should go all out, they'll obviously have their throughput/gas (added a clarification here) limits - just that these limits can be higher than L1. With zkRs, these limits can be higher still. Once all of these are saturated, we always have multiple rollups.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is not possible to have higher security on L2 than L1, as L2 depends fully on L1 security.  If L1 security is compromised, so is L2 security.

author: sky.cactus
content: Or do you mean "limits" as in throughput has potential to be higher than L1?

author: liberosist
content: Exactly this, as per the theme of the conversation started by norswap

author: norswap
content: I guess it's not a requirement indeed. But I don't think people are making / are very excited about rollups whose throughput does not exceed that of the main chain.

author: norswap
content:
I was thinking about this some more.
Has there been any thinking around the idea of jettisonable rollups?
Like you'd have a high throughput L2 chain, but after the state has grown consequently, you'd (a) start a new rollup and (b) considerably increase the transaction costs on the older rollup, incentivizing migration.
Some standardized migration procedure might help.
If the rollup is optimistic, you'd also want to forcefully shut it down at some point before there stops being enough actors validating it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would be generally fine with rollups that had a similar throughput of Ethereum.

author: sky.cactus
content: Mainly because I don't want to throw away too much security (like data availability guarantees) while I would like to achieve some scaling.

author: liberosist
content: I had mentioned this earlier - the solution is implementing state expiry on rollups. It can work very much like the state expiry proposals for Ethereum, with some tweaks given the infrastructure for expired state already exists in compressed form on L1!

author: jadler2664
content: A proposal in the same vein: https://ethresear.ch/t/trustless-two-way-bridges-with-side-chains-by-halting/5728

author: norswap
content:
Not sure what you mean by "exists in compressed form on L1" here?
But yes, I guess the proposed state expiry on rollups would actually work just as well!
